title: German I
requirements: Not for students who have taken GERM2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051 or 4001
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of German to explore the basic features of the German language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written German through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of German grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with some simple daily situations in German such as greeting somebody and exchanging basic personal information with someone in a social gathering, talking about languages and professions, making assumptions, talking about preferences for food and drinks and going shopping.

title: First Step in German
requirements: Not for students who have taken GERM1000, 2000, 2001, 2050, 3000, 3001, 3002, 3050, 3051 or 4001
description: [This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]This online self-learning course invites students without prior knowledge of German to explore some basic features of the German language and culture through a virtual journey. Based on texts, audio and video input, and interactive tasks, students will be able to practice both spoken and written German. This course serves as a taster course for students who may consider taking German courses at CUHK in the future.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to be able to•    understand  basic features of the German language;•    understand selected information related to German culture;•    identify “international” loanwords (e.g. “kindergarten”) as a helpful means to understand vocabulary;•    recognise the relationship between English and German in terms of vocabulary;•    apply basic structures to simple everyday situations, e.g. greetings, introducing oneself and others, expressing food preferences and dislikes, and talking about hobbies;•    implement independent learning as part of their learning experience.

title: Germany Today
description: Germany was a once divided nation with complex historical background and rich culture which continuously attracts international interest. This course investigates trends and developments in contemporary German culture and society from a cross-cultural perspective, taking into consideration the historical events of different generations in Germany. Students will be encouraged to compare and critically analyze the reflections about Germany and their own society. The course content will be presented by up-to-date audiovisual materials. No knowledge of German is required.
outcome: The aim of this course is to let students explore different aspects of German culture and society and make them think about the source of behaviour, customs and attitudes, while comparing with Hong Kong and Chinese behaviours. The famous German poet Goethe included in his concept of culture clothing and food, history and philosophy, art and science, children’s games and sayings, climate and landscapes, economy and literature, political and private life. Although the course can not cover all aspects, it will give students an idea about German mentality and ways of thinking and refer them back to their own background. One needs to be aware of one’s own background to discover the identity of the other.

title: German II
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken GERM2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051 or 4001
2. Prerequisite: GERM1000
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in GERM1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in German in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of German culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in German while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with some simple daily situations in German such as  - Shopping in a supermarket - Talking about family and relatives - Discussing daily routines and leisure activities - Giving/receiving directions and telling time

title: German III
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken GERM3000,3001,3002,3050, 3051 or 4001
2. Prerequisite: GERM2000 or 2050
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with a range of situations in German such as  • discussing one’s living situation; • discussing holiday and vacation; • reporting about Germany and one’s own country; • talking about health and nutrition; • talking about events of the past.

title: Sounds of German
description: This course is an introduction to the phonetic system of the German language, with an emphasis on the similarities and differences between German and English pronunciation. Illustrations and examples will be taken from modern spoken German. Students learning German are encouraged to take this course.
outcome: - To learn about different forms of Sounds in the German language  e.g. dialogues, prose, poems, rhymes, songs etc. - to get acquainted with the German phonetic structure - to improve pronunciation and intonation - to speak better German - to have fun with the German language
syllabus: First contact + Adjustment of standard  The 5 vowels (long and short) The long vowel of O and E and the endings The Umlauts : Ä, Ö and Ü and  the Diphthongs au / eu / ei  The sounds of “ch” and “sch” The sounds of “R”  Holiday (Chung Yeung Festival) The sounds of the numbers   Mid Term Test  The melody   The accent and the rhythm Combination and changes  The tongue-twisters  Final Test
required_readings: Hand-outs will be given during class, contents will include phonetic instructions, reading materials, and homework exercises. There is no need to buy a text-book, although the course of instruction is based on the German phonetic Video Course “SIMSALABIM”. [Langenscheidt: Ursula Hirschfeld und Kerstin Reinke]

title: Exploring German Literature
description: This course is designed to introduce students to some most representative figures in German literature. Emphasis is placed on the critical and analytical reading of their major works in English or Chinese version.All readings and discussions are in English. No knowledge of German is required.
outcome: By the end of the course students demonstrate the ability to  • classify the important periods, writers and works of German literature. • understand and analyze literary works as reflections of the social and political contexts of their time. • distinguish various literary forms, such as drama, novel, poetry and short stories.
syllabus: GERM2100      Topic Contents / fundamental concepts   Periods of German Literature Overview over the development from the beginnings to present   The beginnings “Song of the Nibelungs” (Das Nibelungenlied) - ~1200 - loyalty and betrayal as the fundamental concepts in medieval epics   Literature in the period of Enlightenment (Aufklärung)  -  Lessing (1729-1781), “Nathan the Wise” (Nathan der Weise) – theater to promote religious tolerance   Storm and Stress (Sturm und Drang)  The young Goethe (1749-1832): “The Sorrows of Young Werther”  (Die Leiden des jungen Werthers) –passionate individualism    Weimar Classic: Goethe and Schiller The birth of a national German literature – breaking the barriers of human existence (Goethe “Faust”) and struggle against oppression (Schiller “Intrigues and Love” - Kabale und Liebe).    Romanticism Kleist (1797-1856): “The Beggar-woman of Locarno” (Das Bettelweib von Locarno) – Eichendorff (1788-1857): “Moon Night” (Mondnacht) - the irrational and the mystic   Young Germany The making of modern social drama: Büchner (1813-1837): Woyzeck   Expressionism Kafka (1883-1924), “Metamorphosis” (Die Verwandlung)   Swiss-German Literature Dürrenmatt (1921-1990): “The Visit of the old Lady” (Der Besuch der alten Dame)   Post-unification German Literature Dealing with the past (fascism and neonazism) – Grass (1927- ) “Crabwalk” (Im Krebsgang)   Poetry after 1945 Literature and the Holocaust: Paul Celan (1920-1970): “Death fugue” (Todesfuge)
required_readings: Excerpts of the selected works are put online on moodle  Handouts
recommended_readings: Watanabe-O’Kelly, Helen (ed) (1997) The Cambridge history of German literature. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Kim, Vivian (1992) A concise history of German literature to 1900. Columbia: Camden House. Stoehr, Ingo Roland (2001) German literature of the twentieth century: from aestheticism to postmodernism. Rochester, N.Y.: Camden House.  All books are put on reserve in the University Library.

title: German Cinema
description: German cinema has always captured the attention of the world. This course is an introduction to the history and major developments in German cinema. It explores the language of cinema and the aesthetic strategies used by filmmakers. Through analyses and discussions about the making and content of the films, students will not only get to know the films as entertaining art, but embed them in a social and historical context. Films are screened outside class hours. All films are with English subtitles, all readings and discussions in English. No knowledge of German is required.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students can:  • analyze key works of German cinema since the 1990s • explore the relationship between film and culture/history • talk about differences and similarities between film and one’s own perception of culture • analyze several aesthetic and cultural concepts related to film • analyze film scenes using tools learned during the course

title: German IV

description: This course aims at increasing students' communicative fluency in oral and written German. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. title: German V
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken GERM3002,3051 or 4001
2. Prerequisite: GERM3000 or GERM3050
description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in German with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in German-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to: - describe locations while reporting about features of nature, geography and scenery in Germany. - discuss causes and consequences from various perspectives in discussions of family relationships. - report about events of the past, both in discussion of individual experience and in (re-)narrating stories. - identify basic generic elements of a fairy tale comparing/contrasting these elements across versions.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the units 5 - 8 of the textbook Studio D A2.   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Unit 5: “Medien” Media - talking about media - writing personal messages (sms, email) - making a complaint (about quality) - indirect questions in subordinate sentences: if-sentences, indirect questions with interrogatives - adjectives without article -indefinite pronouns: „niemand, wenige, viele, alle“   Unit 6: „Ausgehen“ Going out - leisure time activities – expressing preferences - reading a restaurant menu - ordering in a restaurant - talking about dating and contacts - Personal pronouns in Dativ („mit dir, mit ihm“) - Relative clause, relative pronouns in Nominativ and Akkusativ   Unit 7: “Zu Hause” At home - talking about living in the city and in the countryside - analyzing property advertisements - looking for an apartment - planning to move house - reporting accidents in the household - modal verbs in simple past - subordinate clauses with “als”   Unit 8: “Kultur erleben” Experience culture - talking about cultural interests - planning a city tour - going to the theatre - talking and writing about events in the past - temporal adverbs “damals, früher / heute,jetzt“ - verbs in simple past - perfect tense and simple past

title: German VI
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken GERM3051 or 4001
2. Prerequisite: GERM3001
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous German language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of German. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of German and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the German-speaking societies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants will be able to use German according to the level A2 of the Common European Framework. This includes written and oral interaction.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover units 9 to 12 of Studio D vol. 2.   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   9 Arbeitswelten Work environments - talking about career paths and career options - analyse job advertisements and CVs - telephone messages - polite requests - connecting sentences with “denn” and “weil” - the verb “werden” (to become) - word formation: verb to noun - wishes, politeness “hätte“, „könnte“   10 Feste und Geschenke Festivals and presents - talking about festivals and customs - talking about presents - compare festivals in German-speaking countries and other countries - prepositions with Dativ - verbs with Dativ objects - verbs with Dativ and Akkusativ objects   11 Mit allen Sinnen With all senses - recognizing emotions - expressing emotions - reacting on emotions - talking about a movie - indefinite pronouns “einige, manche” - verbs with prepositions in Akkusativ or Dativ (“liegen – legen”) - understanding Genitiv - relative clauses: „in, mit“ + Dativ   12 Erfindungen und Erfinder Inventions and inventors - understanding the manuals of products and inventions - working with texts - talking about purpose - describing processes - subordinate clauses with “um … zu” and “damit” - passive voice (das Passiv) with „werden / wurden“

title: German Conversation
description: This course aims to enhance students’ oral communication skills in German. Through selected student-oriented stimuli and topics related to social issues and contemporary affairs, students will practice the expression and exchange of personal views and ideas. Classroom activities may include in-class activities such as dialogue, role-play, narration, speech, group discussion, debate and multimedia activities. Emphasis will be placed on oral practice and an interactive learning environment with a view to helping students build confidence and develop fluency in using the language, to speak spontaneously in social interaction and acquire conversational techniques commonly used in a German-speaking environment.

title: German for Professional Communication
description: The course aims at introducing the basic features of spoken and written business-related and official German language use. Through different types of activities that enhance reading, listening, speaking and writing skills, the students will be able to handle different kinds of business-related and official situations in German confidently. Emphasis is put on the language use of German in genuine professional occasions such as telephone communication, reading and writing official letters, reading job offers, submitting job application, and preparing and attending job interviews.

title: German V & VI
requirements:
Not for students who have taken GERM3001,3002 or 4001
Prerequisite: GERM3000 or GERM3050
description: This is a summer intensive German language course, covering the full syllabus of GERM3001 and 3002.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with daily situations in German such as talking about media (including writing SMS and email), leisure time activities, going out and dating, apartments and living conditions, and cultural interests and productions. The student should also be able to write and speak about events in the past.
syllabus: GERM3051    This course consists of six units: Länder und Landschaften (Regions and Landscapes), Familie (Family), Es war einmal (Once upon a Time), Feiern in Deutschland (Celebrating in Germany), DDR Erinnerrungen (GDR Memories) and Von Schlager to Punk (From “Schlager” to Punk)   Topic / Unit Main texts Speech acts Vocabulary and Grammar Cultural knowledge and cultural comparisons   Unit 1 Länder und Landschaften Regions and Landscapes - Official websites of German Bundesländer - Photos with captions from travel sites - Poems by Theodor Storm - Describing landscape, nature, scenery - Discussing interplay between notions of place and self - Talking about location - Adjective endings - Vocabulary and phrases related to describing geographical location and features of nature and scenery - Preposition with correct case for describing location - Geography and regional diversity of Germany - Portrayal of landscape and scenery in various media - Landscape/nature associated to “home” and its expressive thematization in (German) poetry   Unit 2 Familie Familie - Movie: Jenseits der Stille - Various graphs with statistical material related to the topic of family - Discussing family relationships and family roles including issues of upbringing and role models - Discussing duties, rights and wishes of young people - Expressing own opinion - Language related to describing relationships, family life and upbringing - Past tense of haben, sein and modal verbs - Establishing connections between cause and consequence through subordinate clauses with weil and wenn - Expressing temporal location with als - The concept of family in Germany and Hong Kong: similarities and differences in terms of roles and values - Aspects of values in childhood and upbringing on personal and societal level - Appreciation of film as a cultural product     Unit 3: Es war einmal... Once upon a Time - Fairy tale by the Grimm brothers - Alternative versions of fairy tale (in the form of short film and photo/picture) - Telling and retelling the plot of a story - Comparing and contrasting alternative story versions - Simple past tense (regular and irregular verbs) - Discourse markers for establishing chronology (conjunctions, adverbs of time) - Vocabulary and phrases for identifying and describing prototypical aspects of a fairy tale - Fairy tales as reflection of temporally and culturally situated models and values   Unit 4 Feiern in Deutschland Celebrating in Germany Interviews concerning individual traditions when celebrating birthdays http://www.kaleidos.de/allta g/rituale/geb04.htm Article on the subject of basic manners when dining http://www.lecker.de/deko/di nner/artikel-456654- dinner/Tisch-Knigge-Alle- wichtigen-Tischmanieren- auf-einen-Blick.html Articles on different holidays and traditions http://www.kaleidos.de/allta g/rituale/deindex.htm Describing rituals and traditions Reporting about related personal experiences Comparing and contrasting rituals of different locations Passive voice Reflexive verbs Discourse markers for expressing comparison and contrast Vocabulary and phrases related to describing typical events taking place during celebrations Significant traditions and celebrations of the German speaking countries The cultural specificity of customs and habits during social gatherings   Unit 5 DDR Erinerrungen GDR Memories Graphic novel: “Drüben” Defining the meaning of typical and significant GDR/divided Germany- related terms Describing and discussing relations between personal life and society Hypothesizing on one’s own imaginary choices and actions Relative clauses (with prepositions) Prepositions for expressing causes and consequences The genitive case Conjunctive mood for conditional and hypothetical statements Vocabulary and phrases related to German history and aspects of life in the GDR Coming to terms with the divided Germany as a significant and defining feature of German history Autobiographical accounts of life in the divided Germany as expressions of ‘working through’ the past on both individual and societal level.   Unit 6: Von Schlager zu Punk From „Schlager“ to Punk Selected German songs (audio, video and lyrics) representing a variety of genres (with an emphasis on German Schlager and Punkrock) Text chronicling typical music genres of different decades http://www.nthuleen.com/te ach/culture/popmusik.html Identify and convey main topics of songs Identify salient features of music genres Reporting about dreams, wishes, thoughts of others Compare and contrast music trends across eras, people and places. da-compunds Vocabulary and phrases for identifying and describing features of music genres Music as reflection of temporally and culturally situated wishes and values German Schlager and Punk as historically situated expressions of societal trends.

title: German through Fairy Tales
description: This course is a combination of content and language skills learning. Making use of folk tales, such as Grimm's fairy tales, legends and literary fairy tales, students will enrich their understanding of the German language as well as their knowledge about fairy tales and German culture. The tales taught will be read in simplified versions in German.

title: Special Topics in German
description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of German language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
outcome: At the end of this course, students demonstrate the ability to: - undertake projects that integrate the insights of language and culture studies. - discuss and analyse language phenomena, literary productions or cultural representations of German. - make use of their linguistic, literary or cultural knowledge to critically assess and evaluate productions and representations in German language, literature and culture.
syllabus: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of German language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. title: German VII
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous German language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold at B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of German. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work with a communicative approach through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course, students will have mastered most of the important grammar features of German and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and evaluate past and current issues involving the German-speaking societies.
